I almost glad there no knocking animation in Early Access survival crafting if there were, I be sick of watching it by now and my virtual knuckles would be bloody and full of splinters. I been knocking on forts all night, dozens of them, in an attempt to for Halloween. It not going well. It began well, though! The admin for the a Moose servers was kind enough to help me with a request a way to spawn with a mask. Cognizant of the fact that I might die repeatedly, I did want to have to do any harvesting or crafting for my costume, so she was nice enough to place a few shacks around the servers, link me to the sleeping bags within, and fill a crate inside the shack with pumpkins. This meant I could spawn in the shacks, put a pumpkin on my head, and get right to work. Sure, I was completely naked otherwise, but a costume is a costume. Content warning you can see my dong in the above image Time for! Dressed as a nude man with a pumpkin on his head and nothing else on his anything, I leave the shack and head for the nearest visible fort, making almost fifteen feet before I encounter another. This is a popular server without about people on it, and not all of them ask questions first and open fire later. I dropped so quickly I almost do realize what has happened, though luckily I got a replay the next time I spawn. And the next. And the next. At least I can see the inside of my mask each time I killed, which makes the adventure a bit more festive. I pick a different shack to spawn in, and finally get the chance to actually knock on a few doors. There no answer on any of them, but all this running around lets me admire and critique some forts. A common design theme seems to be em It A Big Box, but I see a few em It A Small Box, several em It a Box With Another Box On Top, and more than em It Part of a Box., in keeping with election season em It A At any rate, the amount of forts is impressive. The server was completely wiped not long ago, and I was a little worried there would be any forts at all. I was wrong there are tons of them. players certainly know how to build. They know how to shoot you, stab you, and bludgeon you. It a community. I knock on some more doors, but no answers. I run into a, the first I encountered who does actually murder me, and we chat for a moment. A few minutes later another goes hopping by, his dong flapping in the breeze. Gunfire echoes in a nearby valley. I see a deer and a horse and a boar. I knock on more doors, even yelling! a few times. Still, no answers. I run and knock on more doors. It begins to rain. A bald naked woman assaults me with an unlit torch, and chases me for a while before giving up. The complete lack of treats I received means I beginning to starve, and soon, I dying from lack of food. heavily armed players run by, and helpfully saves me from starvation by shooting me in the face. I hop onto the other Rusty Moose server hoping to find less bloodshed and more snacks. I visit more forts, including that looks Box forts climbed into a teleporter together and were spliced together to form a BrundleBox. I see a few wooden skyscrapers, at least Octagon, and a homeless shelter I presume for players who have built their own Boxes yet. Still, no is answering when I knock or yell! I living longer there are as many hostiles here but that just means I begin starving again. At point, I eat my pumpkin mask just to stay alive, but running around without it means I not a, I just a naked idiot. I leap from a tall structure to kill myself, but wind up just severely wounding myself, and after I writhe around screaming for a while, I respawn, put on another pumpkin, and head out for last pass. After a long night of running around with a torch knocking on another few dozen empty forts, I see a wonderful sight. It a fort, and someone home I can see a figure on the roof, outlined against the sky. Excitedly, I rush up to the door and knock. There no answer. I peer up at the roof, then knock again. Still nothing. I look up at the roof again, just in time to see the fort owner jumping off it to the ground, where he beats me to death with a rock. Before he finishes me off, I hear him munching on something. In a night spent in, it the closest I ever get to a treat. Happy Halloween.

SURVIVOR SERIES In survivor series we drop in on some of PC most promising survival. Today, Holly Nielsen takes her finest killing rock into. I woke up naked on an empty beach, with nothing but a rock in my hands and an unlit torch. Before I d even had a chance to stand up, someone had bashed my head in. Just before my assailant finished me off, naked people approached, killed my attacker and stood staring at me. While I waited for them to attack me too they looked down, dropped a rock at my feet, and ran away into the distance. My first minute of a was violent, brutal and oddly human. You ve probably heard of as the that people were outraged about as it randomly assigns the gender, race and sizing of your character. This online multiplayer survival has built a huge following and has developed wonderfully bizarre communities. I ve heard stories of warring factions who meet in a neutral ground ruled by a character who roleplays as the Swedish Chef from The Muppets, and people who wake up only to find themselves in a prison built by another. It s a social experiment with nudity. As with most survival the formula of gather, build, die, repeat is found here. The difference that you start stark naked with only a rock creates an vulnerability, and a feeling that you trapped in the embryonic stages of technology. Resource gathering of course involves a lot of hitting trees and rocks and wandering about in search of food and materials. Unlike many of its contemporaries and has a sense of weight. This is a welcome change to the plethora of clones on, where gathering involves little more than pawing at various objects. By gathering resources, crafting objects and killing either your fellow humans or wild animals you gain experience points which can be spent on items to craft. Eventually you ll advance from the Stone Age to automatic rifles. Progress is slow but satisfying. However, once you die you can wave goodbye to your inventory and progress. Unless you ve managed to build a storage, ideally behind locked doors and defences, your stash is either lost with you or looted by your fellow players. Death can come quickly from starvation, dehydration, hypothermia, falling, radiation or being attacked and it s surprisingly brutal when it happens. Your character screams and writhes in pain in prolonged death throes. While playing I have met almost just as many friendly players as those intent on murdering me, which can feel a rarity in online survival. While there s no singleplayer mode, there is still plenty of opportunity to focus on your own survival and settlement building. Of course there are still deathmatch servers if you fancy a spot of. The lack of lumbering zombies often a mainstay of survival, puts the focus on human interaction and all the potential for that entails. Do you run and hide, or risk exposing yourself in the hope that other players will help you out? There s an eeriness to world. Sprinkled throughout the green and often pretty environment there s abandoned industrial buildings that house valuable materials. From time to time an airplane will fly overhead and drop supply crates. These crates become a focus point leading to interactions between players that often end in death. The mysterious planes and dilapidated buildings made me reflect on the chaos happening around and how bizarre the whole thing must look from above. does take itself too seriously. Before too long my character was running about the place with mismatching wellington boots and a pumpkin on his head. Thanks to a pleasant environment design and little humorous touches the pumpkin doesn t suffer from the brown overbearing barrenness that some other survival do. The environment isn t perfect however. I have seen quite a few trees, rocks and dead bodies floating in, and textures pop in and out as you run about. Slow progression can be frustrating as you can find yourself starting again from scratch regularly. Early levelling up follows a similar line each time so you ll be repeating yourself a lot in the early stages of character growth. Fortunately the developer of, Facepunch Studios, is regularly patching and updating the. There are weekly developer blogs on the website that outline updates as well as what the are currently working on. There are regular blogs to keep players up to date on the rest off the very active community. It feels an actively growing product, rather than an unfinished that the developer occasionally patches. For that reason, and the solid amount of interesting features already currently available in its alpha state it s of the most fascinating online survival available. em Disclosure Facepunch writer Craig Pearson used to write for PCG up until about five years

As far as Early Access survival, a is among the most loved. Although Garry Newman is currently working on the project, Facepunch continues to chip away at it under the supervision of lead developer Maurino Berry. of Berry recent additions a XP, which introduced a little bit of structure ie, the permanent short term goal of em grinding. Although the system was welcomed, it appears to be conflicting with the studio and the fanbase longterm vision for the. As spotted by a Berry wrote a reddit recently that, in the future, would not have XP at all. Fans on reddit and in the review section have been vocal about how the system does quite work, and Berry has recently offered his own thoughts. Basically, the system appears to mute the chaos that arises from previously more freeform and less quantitative sense of progress. As I ve said before, the XP system had huge praise until it was, and then lots of people hated it, Berry a in August. I m not deaf nor blind to this, and I m leaning towards the whole thing needing a rethink. In some ways the XP system is the antithesis of what was all about it forces players to do things in a certain order and takes away from the sandbox feeling of the. We this because people were bitching about how grindy hitting barrels and hoping for blueprints was, but I neglected to realize that the randomness could actually lead to some interesting situations and forced you to work with what you had. Berry suggestion that XP will be entirely seems a little informal, and the studio might opt to revamp it instead, but the fact that it a concern is good news for anyone whose recent falling out with the is a result of the grind.

Marauding across lands and clubbing things with a rock just got a touch more structured. Early Access survival epic a has just been patched to include a XP system. From now on, you be awarded points for battering things with rocks, harvesting, fishing, feeding people, and so on. In a bid to reward cooperative, you receive XP for things others accomplish using your tools or materials the system. An example is a Fish Trap, a reads the dev blog. If you make the trap but someone else uses it, you ll get XP. If you cook food and hand it to another and they eat it, you ll it earn as well. If you harvest resources and someone else uses them to craft something a hatchet, you ll earn XP. Interacting with others is the primary means of fostering multiple streams of XP. As you level up, you get a greater choice of items to spend your XP on, allowing you to carve a unique path through the upgrades rather than become a building machine. I suppose it stands to reason that person would have a hard time becoming both master fisherman and designer. Dev Facepunch warns that the feature is incomplete, so expect ongoing balancing work.

a now has a a item, through which players can buy cosmetic items direct from their creators. The idea is that modders can add and profit from the sale of their own work. Perhaps most interestingly, this is all happening through itself using Item functionality.

Head over to the a page a and you notice a option offering Items available for this, including clothing and firearms, that can be purchased for real money. It the first and, as far as I know, only implementation of Item Stores, a function introduced in the latest to that enables developers and community creators to sell items directly to players. The Item exists, and will continue to exist, alongside the a Market, and pricing will often be different. The Red Shine Pistol on the Item, for instance, goes for around, but costs just under on the Community Market the Forest Camo, on the other hand, costs the same on the Item but can be had on the Market for em cents. That might sound a bit sketchy, but product descriptions on the Item very visibly include the Community Market pricing as well. Part of the reason for having the market prices next to the listings is to make it clear to people if the price is lower somewhere else. Items will come and from the item, but they be available on the market as long as people are selling them, Facepunch Studios mastermind Garry Newman explained. And while the Item currently features items as a test for the system, it mainly in place for items. Newman acknowledged that the Item bears some surface similarities to the paid mods fiasco that a so much upset earlier this year, but noted that the products it sells are strictly cosmetic, and they given to players through random, timed drops in the, meaning that nobody will be excluded. I think the a on Skyrim gave a negative vision of what the future looked. Instead of showing how it would lead to better, more supported mods, it showed how you were going to be asked to pay for the shit you were getting for free yesterday, he said. Pretty much all the modders I spoken to would at least the choice to sell their mods. Personally I think they deserve to be able to make that choice themselves. It not a choice that should be made by us, or or by the neckbeards on Reddit. He expanded upon that thought in a post on his a blog, in which he said that approach is good for everyone, including people who ca, or do want to, spend money on this stuff. They hate traditional microtransactions because it s a paywall. But on they the and get random drop items, and can then sell and trade those items on the marketplace, he wrote. It s not unfeasible that a will make more money selling items than the itself cost. Newman said the backend for Item Stores has actually existed for some time now, and that as far as he knows it available to any developer who wants to use it. does partition features off for certain people, everything they add is there to be used by all developers, he said. We just agile enough to have gotten there first. I imagine it wo be the last.

Streaming a or any other survival for that matter can be a little dangerous. If a griefer wants to target you they can tune into your stream, enter your server and troll you relentlessly with the advantage of knowing your every move. Facepunch has noticed this phenomenon, and patched in a tool to stop it from happening. As part of a major which rolled out late last week, Streaming Mode is an attempt to curb the griefing. First of all it tries to hide all server names, so if you re streaming and you accidentally press escape, your audience won t see the server name, the Facepunch spokesperson wrote on the a website. Secondly, it everyone s name to something random. The names are based on their steamid, so the same guys will always have the same names. You ll recognise your friends because they will always have the same random name. That not all the introduces there s a NPC attack chopper, holosights for weapons, perimeter fence gates, an engine, and loads more. forth and survive in peace. Thanks, a Paper Shotgun.

Performance We started adding LODs to the building parts which is having a hugely positive impact on performance. We only done walls so far, but we working through the entire set. What this means is that we using a different rendering mesh for models that are far away, which is lower resolution which obviously does take so much power to render. Because obviously it a waste of time rendering a highish poly model for something that will only be about pixels tall on the screen. We done a lot of work on serverside performance. The AI now thinks at a fixed rate. Previously it tried to think every frame. Race Face Everyone now has a pseudo unique skin tone and face. Just in real life, you are who you are you ca change your skin colour or your face. It actually tied to your steamid. Right now your avatar is randomised via three things. Skin colour, head mesh and head material. We only have face textures and face materials, which means there possible combinations. We will be adding more of these later on at which point your face will probably change. There a lot of skin colours in the world, and it easy to appear racially insensitive when doing this. This is compounded by the fact that everyone is used to seeing this guy as a white guy, so when you see him as a black guy it feels he just blacked up. So we spending a lot of time trying to lessen that effect. There still work to be done, so consider this just the boilerplate of an idea for now. It quite pleasing to see different races working together in, and makes you realise how arbitrary race is. Building Enhancements Vince has been doing a lot of work on the building pieces, having fun with the conditional models to make things appear more natural. I changed the conditional model system so it only runs on model that are close to the, instead of previously where it be running the logic on buildings that were a mile away, and not prioritising nearby buildings at all. This meant that more often than not you were never actually seeing the conditional models. Placement of the foundation relative to the ground is now configurable, and foundation stairs work a lot more naturally. I had to put a bunch of logic in for the stairs placement so that they up or down depending on which side of the placement you are. If you standing on a foundation looking out, it try to place upwards, if you on the outside it will place them downwards. A bit of work was done to make the guide more reliable, to fix problems when it turns red and floats towards the, or staying attached even when you walked quite far away. The building sidewards trick that people were using to build skybridges was fixed. Roof blocks do require to be placed on a floor anymore, you can just attach them to a wall. Vince has made the roof block even more awesome by giving it a vaulted ceiling. Ragdoll Fixes Ragdolls were copying their bones from their parent. This was making stuff look laggy as when the ragdoll spawned the would still be visible, and the ragdoll would spawn in their default stance. This is fixed now so things look a bit more natural. Fog We changed how fog worked to give a better sense of distance. Previously the dog was only showing up in the far distance which looked great in certain situations but it meant that it was hard to get a sense of distance. You be looking at some point on the landscape that you thought was meters away, then see a tree near by that revealed it was meters away. Hopefully the fog will make that less common. Stone Pickaxe Up until now you had to harvest Ore with your rock until you got lucky in a radtown and found a salvaged tool. If you tried to use the stone hatchet you d end up with a broken tool fast. We fixed this by adding a stone pickaxe as a starter weapon. It is the ying to the stone hatchet s yang, Enjoy! Terrain Generation Andr Straubmeier The first version of the procedurally generated roads had a couple of issues where they would take pretty crazy routes or cross each other in ways that didn t make much sense. Most of those should be fixed now, though improving the road network generation is still an ongoing process. We an initial version of bridges which are very much still a work in progress but help keep landmarks connected. With roads doing the right thing for the most part we felt experimental and a proof of concept for rivers. On the hand rivers are great because everyone wants them and they do a big deal to make landscapes look unique. On the other hand rivers are horrible because they come with all sorts of issues that have to be addressed with workarounds that are more or less ugly. They cause between the river mesh and the terrain mesh, fuck around when the terrain mesh LODs and make checks for whether or not something is underwater an order of magnitude more complex. Nonetheless we decided to run with it and rivers to the procedural maps. There s bound to be issues with this first iteration for you re not getting wet when crossing rivers but we ll solve those as we along. A nice side effect of having proper rivers that flow down slopes is that they allowed us to remove a lot of the water at zero level which was previously supposed to kind of look rivers but didn t. This allows for much more terrain elevation and gives us much more freedom when designing the procedural generation. example of this is a huge increase in the number of mountain lines, simply because we have much more space available for them. The terrain shape gives us a lot more freedom when texturing the terrain. Biomes now depend on both the latitude how far north or south a position is as well as the altitude how high a position is, leading to much more detail and variety overall. Further include a warehouse landmark, bigger and more condensed rock clusters, improved sand dunes, nicer mountaintops, smoother texture blending and many more I ve probably forgotten. Packet Errors When we first moved to Raknet were getting occasional problems with entities being missing on the client. The server was sending them but they were showing up. Investigation found that the entities were reaching the client but we had a lot of invalid packets. I a checksum to the entity networking process. Players that were missing entities got kicked. The assumption was that these were network issues, maybe people were on a shit internet connection. But then a lot of people started getting kicked. And it was the same people. The main reason for moving to Raknet was that it a tried and tested platform, so any bugs were going to be in my code. So I spent hours ripping my code to bits, putting it back together in a different order. No change. So maybe it some other code overwriting the memory that contains the packets, so I disabled any other native code we had running which could be a problem. No change. So maybe it some compiler flag in our native dll, maybe it a raknet define, maybe we sending too much data and raknet is tested for it. All no change. After reading through lots of feedback from you guys thanks, I spotted a pattern. It was happening when the packet was larger than the MTU the maximum size of information that fits in a single packet, so it was only happening when the packet had to be split. I set up a bunch of logging which confirmed it. Some packets were split and put back together again, and the that errored out was put back together but we received the last peice first. But surely raknet would handle that right? Surely it would put shit back together in the right order? Nope. We had no more issues with the dev servers since I applied a fix to this, but I be keeping my eyes open. Terrain Generation Andr Straubmeier The first version of the procedurally generated roads had a couple of issues where they would take pretty crazy routes or cross each other in ways that didn t make much sense. Most of those should be fixed now, though improving the road network generation is still an ongoing process. We an initial version of bridges which are very much still a work in progress but help keep landmarks connected. With roads doing the right thing for the most part we felt experimental and a proof of concept for rivers. On the hand rivers are great because everyone wants them and they do a big deal to make landscapes look unique. On the other hand rivers are horrible because they come with all sorts of issues that have to be addressed with workarounds that are more or less ugly. They cause between the river mesh and the terrain mesh, fuck around when the terrain mesh LODs and make checks for whether or not something is underwater an order of magnitude more complex. Nonetheless we decided to run with it and rivers to the procedural maps. There s bound to be issues with this first iteration for you re not getting wet when crossing rivers but we ll solve those as we along. A nice side effect of having proper rivers that flow down slopes is that they allowed us to remove a lot of the water at zero level which was previously supposed to kind of look rivers but didn t. This allows for much more terrain elevation and gives us much more freedom when designing the procedural generation. example of this is a huge increase in the number of mountain lines, simply because we have much more space available for them. The terrain shape gives us a lot more freedom when texturing the terrain. Biomes now depend on both the latitude how far north or south a position is as well as the altitude how high a position is, leading to much more detail and variety overall. Further include a warehouse landmark, bigger and more condensed rock clusters, improved sand dunes, nicer mountaintops, smoother texture blending and many more I ve probably forgotten. Packet Errors When we first moved to Raknet were getting occasional problems with entities being missing on the client. The server was sending them but they were showing up. Investigation found that the entities were reaching the client but we had a lot of invalid packets. I a checksum to the entity networking process. Players that were missing entities got kicked. The assumption was that these were network issues, maybe people were on a shit internet connection. But then a lot of people started getting kicked. And it was the same people. The main reason for moving to Raknet was that it a tried and tested platform, so any bugs were going to be in my code. So I spent hours ripping my code to bits, putting it back together in a different order. No change. So maybe it some other code overwriting the memory that contains the packets, so I disabled any other native code we had running which could be a problem. No change. So maybe it some compiler flag in our native dll, maybe it a raknet define, maybe we sending too much data and raknet is tested for it. All no change. After reading through lots of feedback from you guys thanks, I spotted a pattern. It was happening when the packet was larger than the MTU the maximum size of information that fits in a single packet, so it was only happening when the packet had to be split. I set up a bunch of logging which confirmed it. Some packets were split and put back together again, and the that errored out was put back together but we received the last peice first. But surely raknet would handle that right? Surely it would put shit back together in the right order? Nope. We had no more issues with the dev servers since I applied a fix to this, but I be keeping my eyes open. Assign to Friend Something we been thinking about for a long time. We talked ourselves out of it and talked ourselves back into it. Our primary problem with this solution was that we did that people would be killing themselves to spawn near a friend. Which probably seems a silly thing to worry about. So now I pulling the trigger. The idea is as simple as it could be. You hold E on a sleeping bag that you own, select assign to friend then search for your friend name and click on it. Your friend now owns this sleeping bag and can spawn at it. The list is collected from players on the server and from your friends list. There will obviously be some issues with this. Maybe I will spend a buttload of resources to full your screen with sleeping bags calling you a bitch. Maybe I will make a sleeping bag for everyone on the server to fool them into spawning into my jail. I do think the effects of these things are too devastating right now, so we going to handle them as they become issues, instead of removing opportunities for emergent gameplay. No More Demolishing Demolishing is used properly and mostly is needed, that our conclusion. When you break into someone base and you find their cupboard we do think you should be able to pull out a hammer and demolish walls and doors to find secret rooms. You should be able to remove the entire building in a couple of minutes. You should be able to place a cupboard next to someone who does have, and demolish their base. That seems common sense design. There is legit reason to use demolish. You are remodelling your base. It seems to us that this is something worth sacrificing, worth making people think around. Maybe we add further tools in the future to make remodelling easier, but we need to see how this gameplay before making those kind of decisions. The benefits of removing demolish are obvious. Penetrating a single wall and getting access to your cupboard does give them access to your whole house. You can have multiple chambered safe rooms that take time for them to break into. Your house is probably still going to be there when you log in, even if you have been raided. Continue Reading Too long to post here

Thursday Dev Blogs Updates Remember how we used to release patches on a Friday and then changed to Monday. Well, we changing it to Thursdays, alongside the devblog. The problem with Friday updates is that we lose our weekends because we fixing bugs and in turn that ruins your weekends of playing because bugs unfixed, or we while you playing restarting servers and in the worst cases wiping. The problem with Monday updates is that we tell you what in it on Friday. If there going to be a wipe then playing over the weekend feels a waste of time because all your progress is gone on Monday. And wants to jump on the dev branch because the dev servers are unstable as we need to wipe a lot when testing. So it good for. So we trying Thursday. Close enough to the weekend to give everyone something fresh, far enough away that we can any breakers. We moving the devblog here too because that just makes good sense. Bootstap Error A lot of users were getting a bootstrap error where the would load, it just sit at the bootstrapping screen. This was something blowing up in Unity Analytics. I put a try catch around it, so we should be protected from that now. Animal Hide Clothing Xavier animal hide clothing has made it in. We have boots, a vest, pants and a poncho. There some incompatibilities with the poncho and the vest when wearing them together terrible zfighting but I nudged xavier about it and hopefully something can be done. Footsteps Alex has been playing with the footsteps. He replaced all the sounds, and a bunch of variations for running and crouching. He some a lot of tweaking to avoid playing the sounds when they should be played. I sure a lot of people will be glad to hear that footsteps created by the local are quieter and are played in so it does sound someone is running around you in circles. Metal Tier Vince has done an awesome job on the metal tier. The price and health of all of the blocks have all been balanced to suit the tier and blocks are all wood anymore when you hit a metal block you get sparks, when you hit a stone block you get dust just you expect. Raknet We changed the networking system to use Raknet. This is likely to have fixed a bunch of networking issues people were having, and it even more likely to have created some ones. Raknet is a common networking library which was bought by Oculus and made open source. The main difference between it and Lidgren which we were previously using is that Raknet is coded in, whereas Lidgren is coded in C. Some people will suggest that this should give us a massive performance boost, but I do agree with that, but it definitely should be slower. But we might see other benefits in terms of garbage collection. Raknet is a tried and tested solution so if something is fucking up then we know it our fault and it fixable. That is something we had with Lidgren. This has been a good chance to clean the networking system up in general. We had a few different functions to do the same thing, and some systems that were seriously. Those have all been cleaned up now. Please let us know if this made things worse or better for you! EAC have been patching in the background. We were seeing problems with an error about, that fixed. You should be able to on Windows now. It probably a good time to explain why we have these EAC guys working at this instead of doing it ourselves. We did get into development to fight these battles. Having a bunch of guys who specialise in this kind of stuff means we can concentrate on development. Which is where we should be focusing all of our attention. And so far it working. There are hacks for there always are going to be. But there are a lot less hacks for the current version than there were for Legacy. Something I been considering lately. There are situations where someone will find an exploit, or a way around EAC, and they keep it a secret. Would it be a good idea to start a kind of reward system where people revealing ways around our solutions would get a cash reward for reporting unreported exploits? Melee Raiding Balancing Internally we been looking at how we can better balance the melee vs buildings stuff. When we tweaking these values it can be hard to comprehend just what effect they will have. So we been creating some tools to help us preview exactly what happening. This has lead to a bunch of balances on the melee weapons. I appreciate this is data that the community would to get their hands on and there pros and cons to that. Ultimately the data will be extracted some way or another, and having a bunch of eyes on it guarantees that there less fuckups. But at the same time it takes some of the mystery away from the, and any change we make is immediately flagged up and reviled against. Ultimately the pros overpower the cons so once we have a way of generating it we find a way of making it available, and maybe even tweakable by server owners. Metabolism The metabolism has been working for a while. This means you have died of hunger for a long while. It enabled again now, so you can die of starvation and thirst. The rules are very simple right now. If you have lower than calories or thirst you lose health. If you have over calories or thirst you will gain health. Calories and thirst drop a minute. So if you have calories right now, you have about hours real world time to eat before you start losing health. The part of the metabolism does take into account movement heartrate or heat or anything that right now. This is on purpose to see how we feel about the rates before adding other factors. Localized Damage A while back we had a system where if you shot someone in the head it do more damage than if you shot them in the toe. Then some internal refactoring happened and it did get. Now it reimplemented. And it more accurate than it used to be. You can shoot people in the thumbs. Known Issues Balance is going to be an issue for a while. We still shifting values around and seeing what works. As time goes on this will get more granular and less noticeable until we settle. The upgrade text on the doors is wrong. Luckily we had a bunch of stuff queue up and ready to. I expecting to be doing a lot of debugging over the next few days, just due to the raknet move. Roads and Reloads Roads Andre got roads in! Roads connect landmarks and rad towns. You can walk on them. This is still in the stage, but since it got to work in millions of different procedurally generated maps we thought it was best to get it in and find any problems as soon as possible. Reloading I started making a crazy reload system. Holding R bought up a reload menu, showing your weapon and all the types of ammo that could fit in it. Left clicking an ammo pile would add of that type to your gun, right clicking would fill it with that type. This meant that you could have more granular control over filling your weapon, and when we have different ammo types you could alternate them in your clip. Then we realised that it was all a big load of shit, and would ever want to do any of that. So I just changed it to be normal reloading. Goosey had already made reload animations for everything so it already cool as fuck. Item System A while back we thought would it be cool if all our items were on a website, so we could all edit them easier, and even people who are programmers and do have Unity could edit them and fill stuff out. And then maybe our artists could upload models and materials, and then it would all be downloaded in the and just work. Then eventually we could open it up to the public so anyone could make items, and people could vote on the items and we put the best ones in. We fell into the premature generalization problem here. We were making a system before we knew completely what it was, how it would be used, how it could be used. The items are defined in Unity now. This means that when we want to add a item we just create a copy of the existing item, change a few text entries and it done. In the old system we have to to the site, create a item, fill shit out, to the, download the item definition, then if something was wrong, repeat. There a bunch of reasons why it better now, but they reasons only we care about. For you it means that I spent days making us more agile. Compile Issues We were fighting compile issues for a few days. This meant that the dev server were mostly inaccessible during this time. The problem it turned out was that we had too much stuff. The resources file in the Unity build had a limit, and we were going over that, which resulted in a cryptic error. The hacky solution, it turned out, was to make a scene that had a reference to all the textures, and a scene that had a reference to all the sounds. This made the a lot smaller because it did contain any of those. Shortly after the on Monday EAC enabled the file hashing stuff, which successfully stopped the resource editing stuff that was going on. If you were using this cheat you probably need to verify your content to the version of the files, so it will let you again. At the moment Windows is classed as a cheat. The EAC guys are working on that. Unity Analytics Again, another thing for us more than you. We our Google Analytics implementation and Unity Analytics. Analytics is a funny word to spell, the trick is to remember to start with anal. Unity Analytics only supports iOS and Android right now, because hardly any PC are made with Unity. But we using it anyway. We not doing anything particularly interesting yet, just useful general stuff the number of players, memory usage and the average framerate. Sprint Instead of having to let of sprint for a split second to use your melee weapon and then being able to sprint again, we changed it so trying to use your melee weapon will automatically make you stop sprinting for a very small amount of time. This has the benefit of making melee less hectic as well as more user friendly. Item Condition Gathering Helk has has changed how items lose condition when gathering, and how gathering works. Now each weapon defines explicitly how it behaves when it hits an object, such as how much to get, how much it wastes, and how much damage the item should take. The balance values aren t final and are subject to change but what this does is give us a lot more flexibility to make each tool behave how we see fit. In addition, instead of gathering giving you some of each type of resource contained in the object, it will dispense only type of item at a time. Harvesting will still take the same amount of time as it did before but you ll get less resource spam and more of each individual type per hit. Development Thread We have a thread on our forums where you can post bugs and discuss the development branch. The idea is that this is the place to flag up bugs and problems with stuff on the development branch, so we can look into it and fix it before making it live. This is a thread for suggestions, ideas, bugs in the live branch that you have verified exist in the development branch. Overall Balance I hate that I have to post this every week, but people think we think the balance is perfect if I do. The balance is perfect, do worry, it an ongoing thing. Everything Else Canned food now gives you an empty can when eaten Empty cans can be smelted into metal fragments in campfires! Stone spear now costs a wooden spear plus some stone Sleeping bag now costs cloth instead of Lantern consumes fuel Summary Kind of a slow week. We got some good stuff done, but apart from the roads and the reloading you not going to see any benefits to it. Again, we posted in last week we not releasing an today. It will probably come out on early next week and bad news this requires a total wipe of saves and blueprints. Server owners do have to worry because this happens automatically but I think we got a responsibility to tell you that it gon na happen before it does. Wipes are something we want to avoid as much as we can. Which is of the reasons we thinking about increasing the length of our sprints to or three weeks between updates. Let us know what you think the solution is.

Sprint Instead of having to let of sprint for a split second to use your melee weapon and then being able to sprint again, we changed it so trying to use your melee weapon will automatically make you stop sprinting for a very small amount of time. This has the benefit of making melee less hectic as well as more user friendly. Item Condition Gathering Helk has has changed how items lose condition when gathering, and how gathering works. Now each weapon defines explicitly how it behaves when it hits an object, such as how much to get, how much it wastes, and how much damage the item should take. The balance values aren t final and are subject to change but what this does is give us a lot more flexibility to make each tool behave how we see fit. In addition, instead of gathering giving you some of each type of resource contained in the object, it will dispense only type of item at a time. Harvesting will still take the same amount of time as it did before but you ll get less resource spam and more of each individual type per hit. Development Thread We have a thread on our forums where you can post bugs and discuss the development branch. The idea is that this is the place to flag up bugs and problems with stuff on the development branch, so we can look into it and fix it before making it live. This is a thread for suggestions, ideas, bugs in the live branch that you have verified exist in the development branch. Overall Balance I hate that I have to post this every week, but people think we think the balance is perfect if I do. The balance is perfect, do worry, it an ongoing thing. Sprint Cycle We making this week. We no longer going to release updates on a Friday, because it stupid. We going to be pushing our out on Mondays. The devblog will stay on Fridays. The aim is to have it all ready by Friday on the dev branch, so that the early adopters that have joined the dev branch can test it all weekend, then we can fix any last remaining bugs before making it live on Monday. Which then gives us better opportunities to fix bugs during the week. What we want to do is encourage more people to join the dev branch, so our stuff gets tested more before being pushed to the main branch. Raiding Balance We the automatic health regen on building blocks. Freshly placed building blocks now have full health and upgrading a block gives it full health. You can repair a block with the hammer but it going to cost you a fraction of the resources. Twigs We have a tier of building. It called the tier. It weak and it cheap. The idea is that you can quickly and cheaply lay your building out before proceeding to upgrade it. These blocks are very weak so if you make a mistake it does take long to smash to pieces. Durability We bought back durability in legacy. The idea behind durability is that it will punish you more if you using a weapon wrong. For example, if you using a hatchet to try to break down a stone wall it will wear out a lot faster than if you using a pickaxe. This should make it more challenging for hatchet raiders, especially if you have upgraded walls. Because this is a big change please do expect the balance to be perfect straight from day. It something we going to watch and nudge the values around until it works. Pump Shotgun, Goosey, Alex and Helk have done an awesome job bringing the pump shotgun to the. It feels meaty to use, something from the original Quake. Timed Explosive To make raiding more possible in the higher tiers, and to meet our baseline goals, we have back explosives. The exact ingredients required to make explosives and the charge still need balancing, but the basics are all in. We not sure whether tossing it will stay, or whether you have to up and place it. Ambient Sound Alex ambient sound system is in! Currently it factors the biome you in and the time of day. There a base layer of ambience for each biome and a collection of off sounds that are randomly triggered to break things up a bit. The map no longer feels an empty world, it feels a world that is full of stuff. Gibbing Late in the week we worked out the foundations of gibbing. This is something we were sorely missing, and something that was going to get harder and harder to implement the longer we left it. Vince made some test gib models and I hooked it up. And it works! These gib models are they were just made to test the theory of the system. We can start working our way through the models now, creating gibs for them. Movement There been a couple of to movement. You can no longer sprint sidewards, diagonally or backwards. And you ca use your weapons while sprinting. This brings the movement in line with Legacy and it makes melee fights more feasible and interesting. It gives you an opportunity to bitch about how the movement in Legacy was terrible and this is a step backwards, even though you posted the exact opposite thing a month ago. Other Stuff Fixed stopping when closing inventory menu Fixed chat box opening again on submit Chat has scrollable history Can click on avatars in chat to view profile Fixed too many vertices in canvas error if lots of chatting Fixed cancelling queue craft not returning resources Crafting can no longer take from or give to wearables slots Items are not destroyed if inventory is full they dropped into the world If is full, will spit out items instead of losing them drop notice options to hide Can toggle nudity censor in menu menu settings are now saved properly roof block Fixed supply drop parachute not closing explosives timed explosive charge Voice UI unique loot panels Can now loot corpses clothing Building Privilege UI notices Fixed damage info being sent to the delayed low overlay radius to some projectiles arrows, shotgun pellets easier to hit Fixed scrollwheel not skipping over items that can t be held Summary My main hope for this week was that I could get some of the issues with the UI fixed. But then we got a bit more ambitious. A lot of gameplay stuff. A lot of that are making our lives simpler. And a lot of stuff. We aware that some of the stuff we is balanced. Balancing is something that we can get right on the first release. It something that gets normalised through playing and iteration. So please do be the guy who freaks out on reddit. Next week more of the same. I hoping to get the network system transitioned to raknet which should fix a bunch of network related problems people are having and will probably add some ones that people are having right now.

The With The UI UI System We have switched over to Unity UI system. It not without its problems which they working on but it a lot better than it was. While I moved the majority of stuff over, please keep in mind that this is just under weeks of work. I have been concentrating on moving over the most important or most complicated features. So there are things missing which I working on. Menu Screen We want to make the menu screen less useless. We do want it to be a screen that you use to get to another screen, we want to use it to keep you informed. You can see a tiny example of this now, as we link to the latest devblogs. Server Browser The server browser is a bit more comprehensive than the previous version. We have lists for LAN servers, favourites and history. You can add a server to your favourites by pressing the star next to its name. UnityUI is a bit slow at handling massive lists right now they looking into it, so I limited the server lists to showing the top servers. I be adding filtering and searching tools at some point. Connection Screen A screen. The connection screen shows the connection status. If you disconnect from a server it will show you why. If you press escape in and come to the menu, you be able to use it to disconnect. This screen a bit if a placeholder. I hoping to add more features to this screen that let you have more interaction with the server. Think logos, MOTD, admin lists, connection stats ping etc, reporting. Death Screen The death screen is now skipped if you never been alive before. The left side is a bit empty right now but that change over the next few weeks. The right side should show respawn options. You can now choose which sleeping bag you want to spawn on. If you ca spawn in a sleeping bag because of a time delay, it show how long until you can use it right on the button. You can give your sleeping bags a friendly name in. Sleep Screen The sleeping screen no longer has a wake up button. You can just press a button to wake up instead. Inventory The inventory menu is now full screen and frameless. This has the disadvantage of obscuring all the stuff that happening in the background, but it has the advantage of not looking shit. It might be a bit big on larger resolutions. Next week I be adding some scaling options so you be able to make it smaller based on your preference. Selecting Items You can select an item by clicking on it. This will show information about the item at the top of the screen, along with any options it may have eating food. This area is right now but we have plans that justify its existence. You drop items using this method. I can appreciate that this sucks, next week I add options to drag out of your inventory to drop. Splitting Splitting has changed, and it something you need to be taught. If you select a stack you get a split widget. Simply drag the bar to the amount you want to take, then drag the icon to where you want to put it. But that not all Left mouse button dragging a stack drags the whole thing Right mouse button dragging drags a single item Middle mouse button dragging drags half the stack It our belief and hope that the three clicks required to split accurately is offset by the fact that you probably never actually do that, opting instead of use the mouse buttons. But we see how it works out. Blueprints The blueprints list have an All category. They show how many you have unlocked. You can scroll through the list by dragging it up and down. The items you ca craft because of a lack of resources are at the bottom, the rest are ordered by title. When you are crafting something a timer will show up, along with how many others are queued. You can cancel an item you have queued by right clicking. This is a lot more simplified compared to the previous version and you do lose a degree of control but we see how it goes. Tweaks The tweaks window has been redesigned and has a few options. It shows the framerate, and has a framerate graph along the bottom. This should make it easier for you to see if changing the settings here has any performance benefit. I am noticing now that the grey background gradient is horrible, so I tweak that next week. Let me know what other options you want here. Chat Chat now has avatars and names are a different colour. Next week I need to add history and fix that white line at the bottom of all of the avatars. Vitals Nothing much has changed with vitals. Some of them show a bit more accurate data. That it. Randomized Rad Town Layouts We are currently testing a system to partially randomize rad town and monument layouts based on the server seed. You can look at it as a simplified version of the AI Director in Left Dead. It can for example remove or add walls, buildings or other objects from rad towns to make it harder for people to learn the exact layout and loot positions. The aim is to people to always be prepared for surprises when entering a rad town, even if they have seen this specific rad town type before. For now we are using this system very scantily in order to test that everything works as it should. At this stage it is little more than a proof of concept to see what kinds of randomizations could make sense when we design rad towns in the future, but expect to see or not see some rad town entrances and objects depending on which server you are playing on. Anti Cheat EAC has been turned off for the last week while the guys debugged why people were seemingly being kicked randomly. They done that now so it back armed. Some guys have found that you can fuck about with the big resources file to create cheats. I could have spent time writing code to stop that, but the EAC guys are working on a better, more solution for that, which should be ready quite soon. Summary Man, that been a bit of a crunch for the last couple of weeks but it feels great to have got it all done. I going to spend next week cleaning it all up, fixing bugs, adding back missing features and taking feedback. I the Raknet source code to our native dlls too all ready to be used so I have a at that too which should fix some of the network issues we had with lidgren. Let me know about any you have with the UI either via garrynewman or in the forum.

Lots of stuff happening at the same time this week. Radtown Loot The way loot spawns has been changed. Previously you always find boxes in the same position and most of the time they were empty. Now the boxes disappear when they are looted and respawn at a random position. We ve modified the loot tables quite a bit to be slightly more generous when it comes to boxes in rad towns. You will notice that Rad Towns spawn barrels at random positions. This means no more dummy barrels! There are different tiers for the barrels, some with better, some with worse loot. Updated Terrain Generation Terrain generation was updated with sand dunes including a sand texture, small lakes and steep cliff. The overall terrain resolution was increased by a factor of four, which allows for more details in both the heightmap and ground texturing. The updated procedural generation algorithm provides a lot more control parameters, which means we ll have a much easier time to address terrain layout issues in the future. In addition to the improved terrain shape, the server now spawns around four to five times as many trees per world unit by default and a much higher percentage of the overall landmass is turned into forest. Bush density was greatly increased and they no longer disappear a few hundred metres away but instead turn into billboards that can be seen from any distance. Last but not least, radtown placement was improved to fit the surrounding terrain in a smooth and more way. Join Timeouts If you have a crappy internet connection you probably have been able to join a server in the last couple of weeks. I been looking at it and I hoping I made stuff better for those guys but at the moment it does seem to be a universal problem with Lidgren. I keeping an eye on it and will evaluate our options once I done with the UI stuff. Satellite dish Vince has finished work on the satellite dish monument! It got a lot more rusty. Admin Commands We started a secret chat room for server owners to give us feedback, so have made a few based on that. All of the admin commands should now give a confirmation response. So if you add a moderator, it should now tell you that it completed successfully. removemoderator steamid removeowner steamid unban steamid Let us know if there are any other admin features you would. I do want us to get into a situation where you feel you have to install server mods to moderate your server. UI Progress I been spending all week on the UI. It not ready yet. My plan is to have it ready for early next week, then put it on the development branch for testing and then release it to main on. I have been having a lot of fun doing the UI. Unity UI system is totally without its issues, but I confident in saying it the best I ever used. Summary We resisted putting out patches during the week because they were going to require a wipe so hopefully the I put out after typing this does have any big problems. Something to be aware of is that even though the requires a wipe, it does need to wipe your blueprint progression. So that something at least. Next week we should have the UI and the days of stack pickup hell will be behind us for good. Keep an eye on Rustafied and RustUpdates for more info.

Radtowns and Blueprints Mass Drops We had a long standing problem with mass drops on our servers. After about people have joined, and after a few hours, every few minutes everyone on the server would drop out. This turned out to be a problem with how Lidgren our low level network library recycles packets. The list of packets was growing that large at times that it was affecting performance of the network thread which periodically stalled and stopped sending out data, causing clients to eventually give up and disconnect. This is another of those bugs that we been chasing our tail on for a long time unsure whether it was something we were doing or a ddos attack. It could have probably been avoided completely by using a tried and tested networking library from the start but I guess this is how network libraries become tried and tested. Missing Lock Weirdness This is a tricky to explain, so I not going to bother. Sometimes on the client locks that we on doors were actually showing on the door, they show at the center of the world instead. And sometimes when saving we lose the fact that the lock was attached to the door. This meant that when loading that save the lock would stay on the door but the door did know it was there so did use it. Meaning anyone could open the door. This is fixed. Finally. Jacket Xavier got a bunch of jackets in. For now we only put in the because we do have UI to handle reskins yet, but there a lot of verirty there for the future. Assault Rifle Paul,, Goosey and Helk have got the assault rifle in. It an, but I do think we calling it that in for some reason. Maybe because it got a shovel handle. Bear Trap Will kill animals and players, should be fun to see how this plays out with base defense, eventually it ll actually trap things instead of kill them but lets see how this plays out, corpses of any object that trip it will stick around for quite a while so you can revisit your traps and see what they caught! Airdrop Fixed The airdrop was dropping an impotent package right in the middle of the map. The package it drops is now potent, and it drops it somewhere randomly on the map. The package has higher value loot than can be found in the other loot spots, and you do have to pay for it. Blueprints legacy, you now start with the limited ability to craft items. You need to find and study blueprints to be able to craft items. We still tweaking which blueprints you start with and which you have to find so please let us know. The blueprint data is decoupled from the map save data. So if your server administrator likes, he can wipe the map but keep your blueprint states. In the future I want to look at making the way this data is saved my available to server mods so server providers with multiple servers can share data between them. Radtowns Let me start by saying that this is all placeholder art. We got a bunch of models from the asset and put them together. We figuring out what works and what makes sense using this placeholder art before fully committing to creating our own art. We want more internals, we want you to be able to enter any building you see. The towns work very much in legacy. There buildings, there respawning loot, there radiation. Things might look a bit weird initially because we still experimenting with telling the procedural system how and where to place these, and to modify the terrain around them so they look they been there for a long time. We have big ideas for Radtowns. Random Loot Barrels This is a bit of a placeholder which will be once we have more loot spawning monuments. Around the map you find barrels spawn randomly. Break them to get their contents which can be items or blueprints. This is part of the radtown strategy to give people more of a purpose to roam the island, and make it possible to acquire blueprints. They wo be barrels forever. Everything Else Aiming down the sight provides a recoil reduction, crouching further reduces recoil, weapons have higher recoil in general now Bolt rifle now has no aimcone bullet goes where you aim gravity Fixed corpses not spewing their contents when destroyed Fixed bug where lootables could become permanently occupied Fixed code lock not displaying its status in the world Fixed unducking when opening menu Tweaked how positions were updated over the network clients should get more up to date information now Linux Many apologies to the linux guys. a bookmark Permanent Link to The problem with survival Have you ever seen Survivorman? It s a documentary series about a guy called Les Stroud who spends a week in the world s most inhospitable places deserts, rainforests, tundras and survives with only the clothes on his back. Fakers Bear Grylls have doctors on hand, camera crews, and cosy hotels to return to after filming, but Stroud does it all for real and films everything himself. It s good TV, and I promise that after you watch the first episode you ll be hooked. Anyway, what Survivorman shows us is that nature is terrifying, and doesn t care whether you live or die. These great, lonely expanses, whether it s the dense jungles of the Amazon or the icy plains of Alaska, are cruel, merciless places. Stroud is a seasoned survival expert, and even he struggles to find food or keep warm sometimes. Imagine if you were out there. You wouldn t last a day. So why do survival always have enemies in them? Zombies, cannibals, wild animals it s completely unnecessary. Nature has already done the hard work and designed the most formidable, intimidating, ruthless villain imaginable itself. Survival sim developers seem to think they need to include some kind of threat to keep players interested, but that isn t the case. Being stranded in the middle of nowhere with no food, no fire, and night closing in is scarier than any monster. A survival doesn t need conflict. There are other ways to keep a engaged. There could be exploration elements discovering abandoned camps or ruined buildings, and using them as makeshift shelters. There might be stories to discover, or clues to escaping the wilderness an old map left behind by a hiker with a route scribbled on it. Or imagine finding something Christopher McCandless bus, and reading his diary by a flickering campfire. But for this hypothetical to work, a lot of love would have to be put into the atmosphere and design of the world. You d need realistic weather and lighting, and stunning natural beauty. That s another thing I love about Survivorman Stroud is always in awe of the majesty of his surroundings, but respectful, and occasionally fearful, of them. With a large, diverse, and beautiful environment to explore I d love somewhere a rainy forest in the Pacific Northwest I d the just to wander the landscape and see what I could find before nightfall. But let s say you re an indie developer making your dream realistic survival, but the guy holding the cheque that ll decide whether the project lives or dies insists on some kind of danger. Well, in that case, you do it subtle. You make animal attacks rare, but possible. As you walk through the forest at night, you might hear a growl, or something stalking you. But it s unlikely it ll ever show itself until that, unexpected time when it does, and you have to run for your life. That would be infinitely more compelling than a million shambling zombies. survival that almost gets it right is Miasmata. I love the realistic character movement, cartography system, and being able to forage for plants to craft medicines. But then that stupid monster turns up and I lose all interest. The Forest recently a hidden mode type veganmode on the main menu, but it s clear the was designed with the cannibal natives in mind, and it feels a bit empty and aimless without them. No developer I know of has been brave enough to design a survival without any threat. Who ll be the first?

The Summer Sale is nearly halfway over and a number of have been discounted tremendously, from classic to more recent releases. However, the list of discount titles have included offerings from Early Access and that has caused some discussion among developers. Some developers fall on the side that involving Early Access in the Summer Sale is a boon to their efforts. Their product may not yet be complete, but it would help push their development forward. Others feel that because the product is incomplete, it should not necessarily be treated a finished and that sales should come later. So Shacknews is taking a look at both sides of this discussion with the help of some noteworthy developers in the community that currently have a horse in the Early Access race.

Hey guys, another Friday Devblog. I m going to try to keep this short and sweet. Sorry turned out neither short nor sweet. Network Recode We use uLink in our current implementation of. We have been mostly happy with it. We had issues when we first launched with DDOS attacks. Servers could be taken down easily with just a few packets. When we mentioned it on this site we were surprised by how reactive the uLink guys were. A few DDOS exploits were fixed, and more were discovered and fixed. Eventually everything was fixed, we all agreed that their support was top notch and we were very happy. Then a couple of weeks later the CEO emailed me asking to help correct some mistaken information. He mentioned that they were changing their EULA so that if we made another post about bugs that hadn t been fixed they d revoke our license. From our point of view the only reason these exploits were eventually fixed was because we made that post. We could have easily posted a ticket and waited over months with no resolution again but in the meantime could. Then a few weeks later we got another email asking us if we d to buy a yearly support license. It cost times more than our existing yearly license or we could buy a yearly full source license, for times our existing license fee. I asked what we were paying our existing license fee for. We don t want to pay them for access to their source code so we can fix it for them. But on balance even though it did feel a bit of a we decided that we d made enough money from so far that we could justify the support license, especially with how much their engineers helped us over the holidays. At this point we got distracted with a bunch of other issues then of their engineers made it clear that they ve been told not to help us with any of our issues until we have a support agreement, because they have to prioritize on tasks that are economically sensible. So we decided to write our own networking library. Don t get me wrong, the decision wasn t totally based on pettiness and spite. We have a few technical reasons to do this. To do what we want to do we need more control. Don t worry, this isn t something we decided yesterday. We decided it a long time ago. And the good news is that the implementation is pretty much finished and ready to be tested. I don t announcing intentions, I announcing results We re obviously not going to inflict this change on everyone without testing it properly, so some time in the next couple of weeks we ll have an experimental build up on for people to help test it so we can iterate and evolve. Oh and because we re awesome this implementation lets the server and client in build. So you can make listen servers, and single versions. We re not totally sure whether that s something we re going to make available straight away but it not having to a server every time you change code sure makes development a billion times faster. Other Stuff Here s what the artists have been up to. Dan made some barrels! made a hammer Gooseman made a bear And a Deer When is the next? So what s likely to happen is this. Some time in the next weeks a branch will appear on. The community will be split in. and old. We re not going to take the old branch away from you until everyone is in universal agreement that the branch is the future. And even then we ll probably keep the old branch anyway just for a laugh. So, you wanted of these every week, but not all that much has changed. We re still grinding away on the everything. This code is kind of a virus. The more you change, the more you need to change. You get into the situation where it s quicker and easier to replace existing code than integrate it with the system. That s what s happening. The Item System The old item system was a bit of a mess. So it was. We now load items via JSON. Which is generated by the item editor website. You can add modules to an item in the editor website to add functionality. There were a few features on our wishlist for the item system. Items need to all have size and weight. We need to make items be able to other items inside them. We think this will open a world of emergent gameplay if we can pull it off right. For example, you could possibly put some poison inside some. You could put a key in an apple and feed it to a pig. There s a lot of options here. We re hoping that by being able to add universal components to items this, we ll be able to make the system more open ended. An example of this is the throwable component. The axe, the flare and the pickaxe should all be throwable right? Deployables A deployable is something in your inventory that you place in the world. The deployables system is being too. This isn t such a big deal, because it kind of works exactly the same. But unlike the old system, the system keeps hold of the item. This means that it s feasible to be able to pick deployed items back up. Internally this makes the code cleaner and more generic because we can use exactly the same inventory code to browse the contents of an item in the inventory when it s deployed in the world. Weapons and Tools The weapons system is being too. We ve only just started this so I don t know of any obvious improvements. of our dreams is to make reloading more involved with modern weapons. We don t want you to just press reload and it somehow, in the background, takes your clip out and fills it up with bullets from your inventory, then puts it back in. We want you to into combat situations will your clips loaded. I am probably alone here but I want you to sit in your home, manually dragging bullets into clips. Then when you re in a situation, you ll hold down reload and choose which clip you want to swap to. This way, when we introduce different types of ammunition tracer etc, you ll be able to put them in your clips in a specific order. I m sure a lot of people don t see that as a good idea, but I see it as a good way to nerf modern weapons in a common sense way. Building System We re going to change the building system a lot in this pass. We re not ready to talk about that yet though Clothing We haven t modified the clothing system yet and will probably just make it work without many in order to get the out as soon as we can, then return to it again later on. Timescale All these come at a bit of a cost. You want updates, and we can t get them. We ll try to get the experimental branch in a workable state as soon as possible but right now we re looking at least a couple of weeks more. I know it sucks, and I wish we didn t have to do this. But again once this is done we will have some serious traction to push things in the direction we want to be headed. Source

A lot of people are complaining that we re not giving enough updates on the development of. They have suggested that we start posting weekly about what we re doing. So that s what we are going to do. Even if that means every week we post replaced lines of terrible code with lines of not so terrible code. NO?!?!? We understand you want weekly updates filled with a shitload of content. To make that possible things need to change. So we re working. That s why we haven t been posting updates. I think the important thing for people to realise is that when we launched it was still pretty much a prototype. Most if not all of the code is terrible. I m sure people have decompiled and thought that their decompiler was broken. It isn t that s the code. Replacing this code isn t a matter of programmer pride. It s something that we need to do to push forward. The code is very limiting right now. It s hard to understand and there s too much of it. Once it s all cleaned out we ll be able to push on and iterate faster. If we try to do that now we ll end up spinning ourselves into a web. This is a lot of what we re doing now. Replacing old terrible, complicated systems with clean, tidy, future proof systems. Trading Cards As some people have noticed yesterday we our first set of trading cards. I was hesitant about posting about this yesterday because I knew the comments would be filled with NICE RELEASE TRADING CARDS BUT NOT UPDATES. So let me clear this up. Our programmers didn t make the trading cards. We re programming. We didn t delay releasing updates so we could make trading cards. We wanted to release this set of cards during our early alpha to capture where we re at right now. The hope is that every months or so we ll release a set of cards capturing the state of the, the community and events surrounding it. I think Meg and Rob have done a great job on the cards and the backgrounds, and I hope you agree. Inventory System of the code systems that is getting totally replaced is the inventory system. Why? Well, this. You can literally open any of these inventory files and find code that doesn t explain itself. Code that uses ambiguous variable names. Basically, shit, unmaintainable code. This code is tied very harshly into our old GUI system, NGUI. Which in the next is completely replaced by our system of choice, DFGUI. Which will probably be replaced again by Unity s GUI system when we eventually move to Unity in a few months which is why this inventory code is very much UI agnostic. I know what you re thinking. You don t care what the code is. What does it mean for you? And we agree. It s be a waste of time if we a bunch of code and everything was the same. So we are changing things up a bit, making previously impossible things possible. Here s a look at the prototype UI for the menu. This is obviously quite early in the development and a lot of stuff is missing, but I think it shows a few things that the system has that the old doesn t. It s scalable, so if you re playing in a large resolution, or on the TV you will still be able to see what you re doing. You can queue and cancel crafting items. Text labels are all unicode, which means we can support translations. The biggest change is that it now uses the item system, which is enabled by the item editor which is a WIP. Summary We have been distracted by stuff over the last couple of weeks. I had some business bullshit on my mind. Helk has got some rather significant family health problems. I m back at it hard now and Helk is slowly recovering and getting back to work. We are working for you, but please keep your expectations reasonable. We re still a relatively small. Just because we ve sold a million copies it doesn t mean we re going to hire people. More cooks do not make a better. That said, we are hiring if you re awesome so hit us up! Repost of this

I had died again. For the eighth time I had been murdered by a greedy neighbour. I sighed. It was time to switch servers and try it all again. Usually when you spawn on a a server, there are a few quiet minutes to get used to your surroundings and look around. Not on my ninth reincarnation. The very instant I popped into the world I heard a voice behind me, yelling. Who are you! It was more of a statement of rage than a question. Shocked, I turned and saw him. Silhouetted against the sky, a man stood atop a wrecked building, stretching a bow and pointing an arrow at me. His name was Blazing Bazing. He was completely naked.
